page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H. in my last of the 9
of this moneth, whiche I sent by
M
r
Charles
,
I signified aswell to the
Lordes of the Coun-
cell
, as to yo
r
H. what answear I receaved
from
e
Generall states
, as touching those Ar-
ticles whiche were sent unto me: and like-
wise in
e cause of
Vasseur
to what effect
I had dealt w
t
e
Councell of state
. Who have
since resolved to write unto her
Ma
tie
and to
answear those reasons, whiche I proposed unto
them: whiche I thinke wilbe done w
t
in three
or fouer daies. In
e meane season I will seeke
by all delaies, to differ their proceeding till I
heare from yo
r
H.
M
r
Gilpin
and I have jointly perused those particular
notes whiche were sent unto me by my Lordes:
and because there are in o
r
opinions, by that
whiche we finde by continuall experience in
c
o
versation among them, divers pointes of w
ch
some are sufficiently provided for already, some
not practicable among them, and some others
at
will but minister occasion of gelousie and suspi-
tion, and yet make very litle for
e weale and
good of
e contrey, I thought, under humble correcti-
on, to recommend
at whiche we had observed
to yo
r
H. consideration: as also because there
are sundrie other very requisit pointes to be ad-
ded besides, M
r
Gilpin and I will collect them
together, as they come to o
r
mindes, and send them
unto yo
w
. I have sent yo
r
H.
heerew
t
a copie of
e sentence given at
Utrecht
against
Deventer:
whiche is as muche favo
r
as I ever did looke for at their handes. He
is out of prison and gone to
Cullenborche
to
Co-
ronell Baxe
his cousin germane: wherof
Barne-
velt
having notice signified this day to a servant
of
e Coronel, that he thought the
Count of Cullen-
borche
would not suffer suche a man as Deventer
fol.181v
to sojourne in his towne: and that it were farre
better for him, to receav e a garrison of Englishe
men: whiche he uttered very scoffingly against
e nation, and w
t
many malitious speeches a-
gainst
e poore man, whome it seemeth he will
persecut further if he can come by any meanes
to lay handes uppon him. Howe
e
state of all thinges stande w
t
S
r
Martin Schincke
this bearer
M
r
Underwood
, who is newly come
from him, can certifie yo
r
H. He hath lately de-
feated 2 cornets of
e Ennemie, and taken pri-
soners a 100 men, w
t
60 horse. The
Ennemie doth increase his forces about
Hoesden,
and hath lately taken, in
e Ile of
Bommel,
the houses of
Brakell
and
Poieroyen,
and at-
tempted w
t
flatte bottome boates to passe the
Wael about
Herwijnen,
but was repulsed.
Since it is thought
at he is marched towardes
e house of
Heel.
In
e meane season there
are letters gone from hens to S
r
Martin Schincke
to lett him understand
e daunger wherein
we stand in these quarters, and to require
him to send hither some part of his forces. For
if
e Ennemie shall have passed
e river, it
is feared
at
Hoekelum,
Asperen,
Leerdam,
Vianen
and Cullenborche will be lost, and then
afterwardes places of greater importance.
And
so I take my humble leave. From
e
Hage 15 July 89.
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
